So I’m doing in depth research on design briefs. Someone made a documentary about them called Briefly. (26 mins)

<http://link.brightcove.com/services/player/bcpid1519028538001?bckey=AQ~~,AAAAAASoY90~,_gW1ZHvKG_1U0LqDiRqg6y9siD7-Z_bO&bctid=3851119941001> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DEAiwDfVoAACQUo.jpg>

attachments.title: Disrupt NSA Surveillance With This Typeface
attachments.text: As a reaction to government surveillance, the ZXX typeface is embedded with disruptive designs that are meant to combat optical character recognition processes. The four options for online communications camouflage — called XED, Noise, False, and Camo — each have characteristics that keep them legible to humans, but baffling to machines.
attachments.fallback: Hyperallergic: Disrupt NSA Surveillance With This Typeface

text: I love these sorts of things. This reminds of the anti-surveillance “dazzle” patterns a few designers experimented with a couple years ago
